content:
an afterthought (I already approved recently):
maybe add some 'Mathematics' tag  as a hint that there is a math solution...

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is more math puzzle than a coding one.
Wythoff's game has a wikipedia page with the formula to use.
Without finding this, I would have implemented minimax.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Ok for me!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clean implementation using the golden ratio.

Goal
* Please change:
  â€¢ any number => any positive number (move 1 and move 2)
  â€¢ an equal number => an equal positive number (move 3)
  â€¢ can't play => has no legal move (before the note)
  â€¢ loose => loses
  â€¢ are empty => are initially empty
  â€¢ can't play, so he lost => has no legal move and loses

* Please add the following paragraph above the note:

Both players play optimally. Determine whether the first or second player wins.

Input
* Please change "the number stones" to "the number of stones".

Constraints
* Please state the upper limit of n and m, e.g. 20.

Difficulty
* Consider adjusting the difficulty to Medium.
With n and m not exceeding 20, the game can be solved over a very small state space, which makes it easier than a similar puzzle MisÃ¨re Nim ( Hard, https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/misere-nim ) that require deeper case analysis and move enumeration.

Cases
* Second win - 2 (Test 9 and Validator 9): Please revise both cases such that n > m while the output remains "SECOND".

* First win - 3 (Test 10 and Validator 10): Please revise both cases such that n > m while the output remains "FIRST".

Thanks.
I'm a bit annoyed with that one. It is really easy so solve if we know the math behind this, but hard if trying a naive approach.
thanks a lot for your valuable feedback (I'm also going to learn to speak English properly :D)

No problem ðŸ™‚

Thank you for updating your contribution. I don't have further comments for now.
